I might say in that connection that 1638 demonstrates the quandary created by imposing, by validating the Four Installment Rule.

Because if the Four Installment Rule applies and you are required to make the disclosures, calls whereby 1638, you are called upon to make a disclosure of your finance charge, and the annual percentage rate, and you are supposed to do it precisely.

No one has given us any clue as to how if their economic theory not shared by Congress is correct, how we are supposed to ascertain it, what we have been told is that the Federal Reserve Board doesn't know how to ascertain it and that the whole committee of homers, who opposed these regulations didn't know how to do it.
But we must in hundreds of thousands of transactions each year, do it at (Inaudible) of a liability of $100 to every customer and if criminalized.

Now, it is true that the Federal Reserve Board has suggested not by regulation but by the way informally, in the Solicitor General's brief said, well maybe you don't have to disclose the finance charge and the percentage rate, after all if it’s hard to do.

How that waiver of the requirements of the Act, furthers the purposes of the act, as having brought within the ambit of the Act, a large class of people who everyone thought didn't have finance charges and then say, well you don't have to disclose your finance charges after all.
How that furthers the purpose of the disclosure of credit terms, I don't really see.

But whether or not the statement by the board that you don't have to make those disclosures would bind Mrs. Mourning in her suit or any of the other people who brought suit or indeed would bind any Grand Jury that wanted to begin a criminal proceedings under this Act.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I found Mr. Rifkind that it was now at least declared relatively that, that had it been an entire cash transaction, it would have been a lower amount of total cash?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I thought that was in the briefs stated --

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Let me say that--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Family Publication Service would have done it and 7, subsection 7 of 1638(A), subsection 6, I mean, says that the finance charge maybe designated as a time price differential so to that extent, it would not be an impossible or unrealistic requirement.
Would it?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: If we had a time price differential, that is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well then -- if I misunderstood that--

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Just a second, just to finish with the Act, I just have one last section to call your attention to the Act, the section under which this suit actually arise is 1640, finally wraps it all up by saying that if you violated, if you failed to make the disclosures, the liability imposed is twice the amount of the finance charged in connection with the transaction.
So, Congress apparently thought that the finance charge was there and that it was sufficiently ascertainable to be used as a convenient measuring rod for the really penalties.
It's not -- it's not a compensatory, it isn't damage, it's a penalty.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Isn't it a very big penalty in the circumstances, is it?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: If you multiply it by 250,000 customers then it is a staggering penalty.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, such as what amount, have you suggested the amount in your brief other than saying it was a staggering amount?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Well, they say that they are entitled to the minimum amount of $100 per person, 250,000 customers a year that's $45,000,000.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Congress, certainly was capable of making that calculation, was it not?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It's something like trouble damages and.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: As far as Congress, Robinson, Harman in another case as where Congress left though the act clearly didn't apply.
Let me go now to the -- what you are raising Mr. Justice Stewart.
Our footnote concerning that our discovery quite late in the day, I can see it as a matter of fact after our selling operations apparently had closed down.
That in some few instances, there was indication that some customers who pay cash did not pay the full price.
I thought candor required me to call but to the court's attention but I think it is also totally irrelevant.
The complaint in this action, indeed the second amended complaint does not allege that there was a finance charge.

The case was presented in the District Court on the plaintiff's notion for summary judgment on the proposition that it didn't make any difference whether there was a finance charge or not and the plaintiff had no interest in proving it because he relied entirely on Regulation Z.

The District Court didn't find that there was a finance charge, the Court of Appeals didn't find that there was a finance charge and I don't think at this stage of the game, the plaintiff can now rely on the proposition that maybe there was a finance charge there.
That isn't the case that's presented.
I will say that if there were a finance charge in the transaction, Regulation Z is wholly irrelevant.
We are clearly responsible to disclose it and liable.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is -- it is also clear that there was an extension of credit?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: To me, it is perfectly clear that there was not.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Then what did that the District Court say?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: The District Court said that the letters written after the contract, the dunning letters written to Mrs. Mourning, evidenced that, it was credit that the non-cancelable provisions of the contract, the statement of the contract was non-cancelable, needed a credit of transaction.

And it's one of the ground that the -- I think there is an exemplary of the grounds he went on, he certainly did not rely on the proposition that FPS, Family Publication Service had incurred cost and paid money to publishers which -- there is nothing in the record to support except these dunning letters.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Did the District Court say that the defendant has extended consumer credit within the meaning of the Truth in Landing Act?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Yes, he did.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that a finding or not?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: I think that's a conclusion of law.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And what he decided -- he concludes, whatever you want to call it anyway?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Yes, he did.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that was tried out.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: There was no trial.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I know it was on affidavits, wasn't there?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: There were affidavits.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So they were matters besides the pleadings taken into account.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Only the dunning letters that have been described.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, the answer is yes then.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And so there was -- and the court did enter a summary judgment.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And in the course of that, he said that.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now did the Court of Appeals do anything about that?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: The Court of Appeals did not reach the question as all the parties here agree.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So are you suggesting that we should decide the case on the basis of, there wasn't that credit transaction?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: I think that on the -- since the only document that is relevant, is an document that all of the parties, I think concede as an unambiguous contract and that is, that is what tells you whether it's a credit transaction as a matter of law or not.
That this Court could readily proceed to determine that this was not a credit transaction.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The regulations certainly doesn't make any relevant whether it was a credit transaction?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Well.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It does with respect to the finance charge.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: It does and I must say as I read some of the opinions that have been issued by the Federal Reserve Board, they seem to be reading out the credit requirement of the Act as well.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The regulations doesn't seem to.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: It's not the regulation, it's more the regulation as applied that lead to reading it out because what they keep saying that they are interested in is disclosing the sum total of installment payments and they have gone after getting the statement of the sum of installment payments to be disclosed but installment agreements, not all installment agreements, are credit agreements and that's perfectly fundamental, and I think the Federal Reserve Board has lost track of that.
An example was given in one of the hearings --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But maybe not in this case.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: I think they have lost track of it in this case too.
I should say that the government below declined to take a position of whether it was credit and expressed no opinion at all, in its amicus participation.
Perhaps that was why Fifth Circuit never reached the question.

I am not quite clear what position I take on the credit question here, it seems to me quite clear, if you look at the opinions, opinion letters that the board has issued that they are reading out diminishing the requirement of credit in these installment contracts.
Now that's the underlying rationale of what they are trying to do here.
They keep telling us, you don't have to disclose the finance charge that would be too hard.
But what you have to disclose is the sum total of installment payments.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Was there an objection to deciding the case on summary judgment?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: No we were cross motions for summary judgments.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, wasn’t one of the relevant question in the case of whether or not there was a credit transaction?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you say that that was a really a legal question on which you really couldn’t find anymore facts other than the contract and the letters may be?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: That's right, that seems to me that the contract on its base is really the answer to whether or not it is, that's what the district judge thought too, he said the acceleration cost, their brand, I have forgotten, the non-cancel of the provision and perhaps also the dunning letters, came together to support that conclusion.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But wouldn't have it been rather relevant on that question to know what the rearrangements were between Family Publications and the publishers?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: No I don't think so--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Let’s assume for the moment they actually had paid the publishers, a sum of money on behalf of the customer.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: I would think that when I go to buy a car on time from General Motors' dealer, it really whether my relationship with him is a credit relationship, doesn't depend upon whether he has already bought the car from General Motors and he has been holding it or he plans to buy in the future from General Motors.
It seems to me the question is, is he extending the credit, not what he is doing with his money, how he raises his money.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well it certainly -- I mean otherwise, you would think as Mr. Justice Stewart told someone else have brought out, it might be that the buyer was extending credit to the publisher, paying in advance for his service.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: The buyer is extending credit to the publisher that is exactly what is happening here.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well not if the intermediary Family Publications has already paid the publisher, that's why I say the fact that might be a irrelevant fact.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: The District Court didn't hear--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: May be you have forgotten about fact that we say it must be on the plaintiff side not yours?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Well, our answer to the complaint did say at no point during the life of the contract has defended, that's FPS paid money to a third person or supplied goods or services to the customer for which reimbursement is expected from the customer in the future.

The fact of the matter is that we paid magazine publishers after we received payment from the customer, and that is not clearly established in the record, but District Court thought it was irrelevant, and not necessary to its conclusion, and I think the grounds on which the district court relied are legal error.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Assuming that by everything you say up to the point as a fact that once she misses one payment, she is trouble.
For example, if you only pay $3 a month or three, $1 book, that might not be credit.
But if the contract provides that you must do that for three years and failure to make one installment accelerate, isn't that an entirely different --

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Marshall, one of the reasons for acceleration clause is precisely that we did not care to become creditors; we wanted to be paid in advance.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: All of it?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: We were willing to be paid at sort of double the rate -- but if they fell into the pot we wanted the whole amount in advance but we didn't want to be sending magazines to people who had not paid us.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So that when they pay their whole amount, if they had a credit relationship then?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Yes we would be substantially in Mrs. Mournings' debts.
She would have paid us $122, three magazines.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Isn't that in the original contract?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: That is in the original contract, it says--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then why isn't that a contract of credit, since it's in the contract?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Well, if it's credit running from Mrs. Mourning to us the Act doesn't apply because it only applies the other way around.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well I didn't agree for that.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Yes, the answer is it applies only to consumers.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Refkind early in your colloquy with Mr. Justice White I thought I heard you say that on the record as it now stands the Court was in a position, this court is in a position to reach a determination that there was no credit transaction, that was the sentence essentially?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: On this record could we reach the contrary determination?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: I think that on this record, it will at least to be remanded to the Fifth Circuit to consider the question.
It seems to me there is a difference between affirming with the Fifth Circuit on another ground that it didn't reach and reversing it on a ground that it didn't consider.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Even if it's a pure question of law that would be the --

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: I think it would be more conformable to the normal practice of the court in those circumstances to remand it to Fifth Circuit and that may be in the last analysis you have to remand it to the District Court for an evidentiary examination of the question.If I am right then you can answer the question on the face of the contract, it seems to be, it can be answered here as well as in the other court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well isn't that strange for the court to figure that it must invalidate the regulation unless it assumes that the fact that triggers the regulation is it present in the case?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: I could see the court saying that it ought to reach the credit argument first, I think it was thrown off that normal course--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Was that in major litigation before the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: It certainly was, argued late, I think the thing that may have deterred from deciding it, is that justice department came in and said we must have a ruling on the validity of regulation.
We express no opinion on the credit question.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And they got it?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Just to pursue the credit question once more in the legislative hearings, I think the Chairman of Federal Trade Commission was asset to the Senate Committee.
Suppose I hire my neighbor's son to come in each Saturday and mow my lawn and suppose I agreed to pay him a dollar each Saturday after he has done it.
Is that a credit transaction?
And after a lot of legal talk, the answer was no, there was no finance charge and there was no credit, so I understand.

That seems to me a perfectly normal, healthy example of an installment arrangement in which both sides are contractually obligated to continue rendering performance over a substantial period of time, but not a credit transaction, because --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But where is the enforceability of this long going operation as compared to the enforceability here?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Well I suppose that the shrewd youngster would say now Mr. Gentleman before I agree to mow your lawn and forgo mowing other people's lawns this summer, I want you to write me a promise that you will pay me a dollar every week, I don't want you to move it off to the seashore and leaving the — without a lawn to mow.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How long ago was that somebody mowed a lawn for a dollar?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: I confess I don't have a lawn just about sure.
The analogy to our case is I go to my news stand and say to the, maybe on safer ground and say to my news dealer I would like to get the Manchester Guardian on Friday.
He says I am sorry I will only get it for you if you will promise to come in and pay me every Friday.
I said sure and he does it.
Now we are bound, he may be bound for a year or two years or whatever deal I make for it, but neither of us has extended a credit to the other.

Now, if he was a (Inaudible) news dealer, as FPS was and said, look, how do I know you are good to me, you pay me on Monday and I will have Manchester Guardian for you here on Friday, a fortiori, no credit has been extended to the consumer, to me.
By the contrary I have extended credit to the news dealer and that is exactly what happens in the FPS transaction.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well that's certainly true on a prepaid subscription to the publisher himself but this was a tripod type arrangement and it has been suggested that payment was made by your client to the publisher and your client thereby became creditor of Mrs. Mourning.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: There is nothing on the face of the contract that it would suggest that it was a tripod type --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well you are not a publisher of the magazines, your client were?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Yes, that is correct, but neither is the departments or the manufacturer must do things as loyal department store.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But most of them have a gradient stock and make delivery don't they?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: They do.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: FPS has nothing except probably a general understanding that when as and if they send in a subscription with some money on some terms, contract will then occur.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: I think the key thing though is that if the magazine doesn't get delivered it is perfectly clear that FPS is liable, not the magazine publisher.

This is not a subscription with the magazine publisher, it is a subscription with all the rights flow from FPS to the customer and indeed serious problems have arisen where for example the Saturday Evening Post, or Look magazine closes down.
It is the PDS it is called, Pay During Service magazine sales organization that may well be left holding the bag, unable to perform a contract which it undertook to perform.
There is nothing except for the fact that it says delivery will come from the publisher's office.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I suppose your client either makes money or the finance charge or it's a discount from the magazine.
You are not in business for nothing?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: No we are not the required to be.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So on one end you are making money of one end to the other, either in your purchases or on your sales?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: We charge customers more than we are charged by the magazine publisher, exactly right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But you are an independent organization?
Not part of the merchandising arrangement of the magazine itself.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you are not an agent; you are not an agent.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: We are not an agent.
It happens that FPS is on wholly on subsidiary typing, but it deals in the magazines of a lot of publishers as well as (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You suggested I think earlier there is no primitive contract between Mrs. Mourning and the magazine, but if promptly as was contemplated after the making of this contract, FPS did contract with the magazine, would Mrs. Mourning be possibly a third party beneficiary who could enforce that contract?

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Well, I think that would be difficult.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well I am speaking in just the pure legal terms.

turn.speaker: robert_s_rifkind
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Rifkind
turn.text: Yes.

I think not because in fact the arrangements with the magazine publisher sort of invoke not just as I understand for Mrs. Mourning but for some substantial group whatever came in that week and I don't know whether she had a pro-rata interest in that, may be as a member of class she does.
I think though that, go back to the Manchester Guardian, my news dealer didn't have it in stock either, he had to order it in some place but that didn't make him my creditor.
Similarly, here the fact that FPS doesn't have the magazine or the newspaper in stock doesn't make FPS a bank in a relationship between Mrs. Mourning and Holiday.

I also urge that the court may feel that it has to reach the credit issue in all events here because assuming that the government's thesis that somehow there is always a finance charge buried in credit transactions, assuming that has any validity the Four Installment Rule even under that theory could not logically or rationally extend to non-credit situations and if that's what they mean, they mean really to all installment contract situations where there is no necessary or logical implicit finance charge then it means to me the rule has to be over broad by all text.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Rifkind.
I think all of your time is consumed on the other side.
The case is submitted.
